description: Buy the Fjallraven Greenland Top 20-30L Backpack online or shop all Accessories from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: Greenland Top 20-30L Backpack
hasVariant.description: Buy the Fjallraven Greenland Top 20-30L Backpack online or shop all Accessories from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: The backpack is ripping apart after 1,5 year - already hole at the bottom of the backpack. Color fading occurred very soon. Too expensive for the poor quality. Very disappointed.
review.name: Poor quality

review.reviewBody: I bought mine in 2019 and  I used it a lot to work. Unfortunately the bottom at the seam is ripping open since a year or so. And I am not walking long distances because I live next to my work, I just have to cross the street and change places within my work a couple of times. I think if I would have used it on longer walks it would not have lasted more than 1,5 years. The backpack is quite expensive and for that this should not happen. A weak point like this should be dealt with and customers should get a replacement then. I love the look but on long walks with a full backpack it will be uncomfortable.
review.name: Poor qualitiy for the price

review.reviewBody: I do love this bag for its look, but not its functionality. I have two big gripes with it however, and neither are the seam problem that others report. Firstly the water 'resistance only lasted about 6 months, it could have been less as I first got the bag in May and by the early Autumn it could not withstand a 10 minute walk from the bus in the rain. I purchased the wax to re-waterproof it, but each time I have used it this leaves unsightly streaks over the bag and doesn't even seem to protect the bag from even light showers. I know the bag is stated as water resistant but I don't see how it can be called as much, It's frustrating as I've had to purchase a bag rain cover to protect my laptop and sketchbooks. The second problem is the very tight water bottle pockets, with redundant poppers on them. At first they look to be the right size but when the bag is full it is near impossible to get a relatively slim 500ml water bottle in the sides. It becomes impossible because of the metal poppers on each side preventing the bottle to be able to be squeezed in. I had to remove these in the end because it was just too frustrating. Even if the pockets had a panel of elastic it would avoid this problem
review.name: It has the look, but not the functionality

review.reviewBody: I can't leave with it and I can't be more happy! I have use my bag everyday for the last 4 years, for cycling to work, climbing, travelling and of course for many adventures! I do have re-waxed it a couple of times and care for it, as minor holes are obviously happening but nothing that can't be fixed to extend the life of this fantastic bag!
review.name: Best bag I have ever have

review.reviewBody: Mine has lasted 3 years and I adore it and had many adventures together! I'm really sad that it's finally starting to wear out. As others have said, the area where the base meets the back wears through and the fabric thins to the point of ripping. I'm going to try and patch mine to keep it going, but it will be retired from daily use. If Fjallraven were to reinforce this area with harder wearing fabric it would last a lifetime. I love everything else about it! (also Fjallraven, if you're reading this please also add a bit more padding to the base of the laptop sleeve, the protection is fine but not excellent)
review.name: Beautiful pack with one weakpoint

review.reviewBody: I love this backpack, I have it for a year. It is spacious, waterproof and very comfortable. I carry my laptop and basic staff to the office and I am super happy with it each day.
review.name: Loving it!

review.reviewBody: I bought this rucksack (Dusk colour) a few weeks ago for my everyday commute and I’m very happy with it. It fits well, good quality and lives up to my expectations for this kind of bag.
review.name: Nice and light rucksack

review.reviewBody: Bought the black version of this rucksack in 2019. Ended up still using my old rucksack as I found it too small for my everyday commute. This means I used it maybe once every two weeks on average, if at all. A few days ago I noticed that the seam that connects the bottom with the back has completely teared, which makes the rucksack unusable as the bottom is now wide open. I was never carrying heavy items in it. This simply can't happen after three years of less than average use considering the price. Rain water also easily collects on the top of the rucksack, sinking into the top pocket, as the top automatically shapes itself like a dent. Not great when hiking. The only time this doesn't happen is when the rucksack is overpacked to the very top, but then it's uncomfortable to wear due to the badly distributed weight. It's a very good looking rucksack, but I can really not recommend it unfortunately.
review.name: Looks good, but the quality is beyond poor

review.reviewBody: I'm on my second Greenland Top bag now, and the same has happened to this one that happened to the first: the back bottom seem has worn completely through. This is caused by the seem rubbing against the wearer's back.  The seem needs to be moved or eliminated altogether.  Otherwise it's a great bag, spoilt by one fatal flaw.  It's undoubtedly okay for very occasional use, but if you can't use it everyday expect it to last under a year.
review.name: Poor design

review.reviewBody: I recently got this bag in Chestnut and it is so pretty. I really like the way the brown looks with the leather logo cause they compliment each other really well. I typically use it for my climbing gear going to and from the gym and it's perfect because its got the top-loading drawstring going on at the top so you can throw all your stuff in then just kinda can shut the top on it. It fits a good amount of stuff and the material is durable so I feel confident taking it to crags for outdoor climbing without harming the material if it bumps into anything. I also used it for traveling recently and it was great for under my seat on the plane. 10/10 would recommend!
review.name: Perfect climbing and travel bag

name: Greenland Top 20-30L Backpack

description: Buy the Black Diamond HiLight Tent: 3-Person 4-Season online or shop all Hike & Camp from Backcountry.com.

hasVariant.name: HiLight Tent: 3-Person 4-Season
hasVariant.description: Buy the Black Diamond HiLight Tent: 3-Person 4-Season online or shop all Hike & Camp from Backcountry.com.

review.reviewBody: Forget how beautiful and visable the color is against fresh white snow! This tent can handle 2.5 ft of heavy wet snow loading, as I discovered LAST winter in the Catskill Mountains, NY. Now I have 100% complete confidence that it can handle 40-50 mph winds, that is wind, NOT gusts, as well. For myself solo, the 3P with vestibule is my Kingdom. Sharing the tent with friend was acceptable. Not too cramped and we were able to melt snow, cook, eat, lay down, sit up, lounge, stretch, sleep, hang out, change clothing and not bump heads. Plenty of space. The vestibule, I feel is mandatory in bad weather.. Definitely with 2 people in there and if you plan on being mostly tent bound. The entry doors/bay windows are fantastic for views and ventilation, let a!one entering and exiting. My only 2 grips are small, tight toggles and latches for the doors! Very hard to do in freezing weather, bare handed.. With gloves even harder, but this is something I can probably modify myself, or not, because its not that bad, just could be better. The 2nd gripe is the storm flap on the vestibule door can snag easy if you not careful. And in bad weather sometimes you may want to close it up quickly... So be careful. But that's the vestibule and this is review of tent.. So disregard. I wish I could post pictures of it in action. I also love the blue on the inside!! Its cheery and inspiring even on the dark gloomy days..stimulate the mind a bit!! This tent is almost the unicorn! Search it on you tube!
review.name: Powerful Fortress

review.reviewBody: this is a great tent for the features. vented enough for summer, waterproof especially with the vestibule on, and long enough for 6+ footers. truly 4 season. only concern is durability...
review.name: amazingly versatile

review.reviewBody: Finally got to test the Hilight 3P tent with Vestibule in the Catskill Mountains, NY with some snow! Forcast called for 1-2 feet of snow fall.. Mother Nature had other plans for us those 2 days. Upon arrival there was already about a foot and half snow on the ground. When the storm hit, we got approximately another 2 - 3 feet of heavy wet snow.. and counting!! The Hilight held its own and without a glitch. I was safe and dry and comfortable inside while the storm dumped massive amounts of snow through the night. After this trip, I can safely say the Hilight 3p tent with Vestibule can handle heavy wet snow loads without question. For 1 person, this tent is a palace to live in while riding out a storm. You can easily get 2 people in there if needed and 3 would be squeezing, but in emergency situation, it can be done. I prefer the 3P over the 2P for numerous reasons, 1 obviously the extra room for extended time in there, and 2, both massive side door entries!! Just WOW! You can get silly views, plenty of venting, and escape door if snow burries your Vestibule.. just so many benefits over the 2p for minimal weight penalty.
review.name: Great for heavy wet snow loads

review.reviewBody:
I have used it for two years now. I use it when paddling and often camp on rocky islets. When it's up it's ok but the pinching, I find awkward att best. No setup on Youtube shows you the full set up. The poles constantly shift or snags the inside during set up. The welcro tabs is to smal and fiddly for handling with cold hands. I have had the poles missing the grommets and punching a couple of holes in the floor. It's a little easier when ground pegs can be used. I would like a instructional video on the set up, not using pegs. Se the MSR Advance Pro for a dirt simple set up in comparison.

On the plus side of things: I like the idea of the self supporting tent. I like the two doors on the sides, it makes living more comfy. The single wall construction works ok when there is no vestibule and ground condensation is kept on the outside. I wouldn't use this tent in a week long trip in a wet place or on an expidition. For weekend trips in nice weather there are others that are lighter, simpler to pinch and cheaper.
review.name: Awkward to pinch

review.reviewBody: Have used this tent in multiple climates and terrain. It’s the perfect size for 1 person with a good amount of gear. Will work for 2 people. Holds well up to water without vestibule. Confusing to set up at first with poles used inside of tent. Very lite weight tent for back packing. Kept warm in 20 degrees and held up in 50+ wind. I do recommend buying vestibule to use for gear storage and heavy rain.
review.name: Perfect for 1 person

review.reviewBody: I would say that I am 6’2” 205lbs and me and another person for pretty snug. I never had to fit three but even going HFH would probably be too tight.
review.name: Great tent!

review.reviewBody: Incredibly strong light weight tent. Those don’t normally go together. BD nailed this though. Used on numerous bikepacking trips in a variety of conditions from our right rain downpours to moderate snow. Stayed dry every-time and the internal pitch is key. Excited to finally own one of these tents and use for more years to come. Tents are 4 season which = smaller internal dimensions. I bought the 3p for use as a good 2p or big solo.
review.name: Excellent single wall tent

review.reviewBody: I’m 6ft and slim and shared with my two sons (10 and 8). We all fit well with room for gear. Set up was pretty simple but not terribly easy with the interior pole situation. The interior Velcro system to hold the poles isn’t perfect. Overall, for the size and packable weight, I’d 100 percent buy again.
review.name: Great for me and my two boys

review.reviewBody: This is a great tent for the money. You can check out all the specs for yourself on how it stacks up against competitors, so I won’t bore you with that. It’s kind of awkward to set up in that the poles are supposed to nest into the female portion of a snap. This isn’t overly difficult and will likely make the tent last a lot longer, but it does pose a slight challenge to get it right. Kind of a bummer that the vestibule isn’t included. Overall it’s a good setup though.
review.name: Very good product

review.reviewBody: This is a great lightweight shelter with a little extra room for 2. As a single wall tent it does pick up a bit of condensation on the interior. While expected, this is less than ideal for backpacking. The vented design of this style, particularly the 3 man with 2 full doors, can help due to the large screen areas.
review.name: Great for intended use

name: HiLight Tent: 3-Person 4-Season

review.reviewBody: These are fantastic to wear in the climbing gym. The fit is great for lead climbs and top-roping and the rubber inspires confidence on small foot chips. They're also great for working crack boulders and routes at the gym. If you've been considering slippers for climbing, just do it!
review.name: Perfect Gym Shoes

review.reviewBody: Awesome mocs - couple months in with these being main shoes for everything from gym to granite. Would definitely recommend for an all day comfort shoe. Downsized a half size and they stretched perfectly. For sure not technical shoes but the heel stays tight on my narrow heel on hooks and the toes fit just right. Hope to get another couple months at least out of these but will definitely buy again.
review.name: mocs

review.reviewBody: These are my first climbing shoes and they are okay for my first ones. These shoes are very narrow and since they are slip on, it is kinda hard to loosen them up. I recommend a whole size up if you are looking to buy these.
review.name: Evolv Rave Climbing shoes

review.reviewBody: Just purchased my 4th pair of these. My go to shoe for the gym sport climbing and bouldering, multi-pitch trad, and moderate sport climbing. I have a few pairs of La Sportiva TC Pros and Miuras that I haven't touched since getting my first pair of Raves. They feel really secure for moccasins and I rarely feel like my heel is loose or liable to slip out - even with heel hooking. They're so comfortable I often just leave them on for my whole session, but I don't feel like I'm sacrificing performance for comfort at all... amazing! My street shoe is a 9 and I wear an 8.5 for this shoe.
review.name: My Favorite Shoe

review.reviewBody: These shoes are my daily wear for just about any use on the wall. I’ve done a small amount of crack climbing in them, works just fine (not perfect, a better option is definitely a lower profile, laced, shoe, like the Yosemite). They’re satisfactory for overhanging features, accept aggressive heal hooks! I only ever feel slippage when aggressively heel hooking, like a brutal mantle. Perfectly fine on slabs and for smearing. Fine edges are manageable down to about 1cm. Extremely comfortable. I’ve got a medium, normal, arch in my feet. I’m usually a size 9.5US men’s, but I’ve got these in 8.5US men’s for a bit more response (I typically recommend sizing down just a bit). 99% of the time I climb I’m wearing socks and have had no issues with the sizing. They’ve stretched a little but I can still wear them for hours at a time. They’re quite durable too! Indoor use is fantastic, outdoor use is great as well. I’ve recommended these to multiple friends and they absolutely love them. This shoe will always be in my bag and I hope that this quality and standard remains! Thanks Evolv!
review.name: Workhorse

review.reviewBody: I got these thinking they'd just be a chill gym shoe- they've turned into my go to outdoor shoe and they haven't let me down on any edge or smear yet. I've worn these on several long outdoor sport multipitch routes and although I do need to take them off occasionally for belays, so did my friend with his [very famous double priced shoe]. I really like the heel tension although that's the part making me want to get my feet a rest. I've only done a few jams but they did fine. I do kind of wish I got 1/2 size up to wear more comfy with socks. I wouldn't say these stretched a lot but they noticeably became more comfy by the end of the first multipitch day. Don't stop making these! I promote these hard!
review.name: LOVE

review.reviewBody: It was a sad day when my Boreal Kryptos finally died, they were my go-to pair of shoes and I had bought several pairs. After searching for what was seriously a year, I landed on the Rave. They're a pretty neutral shoe, easy to break in and comfortable as all heck. So far these shoes have only been in the gym, but they seem like they'll do well out in the wild too. Stoked to find a new favorite shoe!
review.name: After Searching High And Low, I Found The Rave

review.reviewBody: Comfort, durability and cheeto feet are in your future if you choose these shoes! I spend 24 hours straight in these and didn't feel the need to take them off once!
review.name: Old Reliable

review.reviewBody: I love this shoe!
review.name: Awesome Shoe

review.reviewBody: This has become my all around shoe. It's good for your typical boulder sesh, slab, and crack climbing. I went down half a size since these will stretch out a little, but right out of the box they were comfortable enough for multipitches and keeping them on while belaying. The rubber has lasted me a long time and the fabric has held up even after many crack sessions. Your feet will turn yellow the first couple times. The 5.10 moccasyms have too pointed of a toe for me and these were the perfect alternative.
review.name: go to shoe

name: Rave Climbing Shoe

review.itemreviewed: Dissector Wide Trail Dual Compound EXO/TR 29in Tire
review.reviewBody:
This has become my favorite all-round trail tire for dry, moderately loose and rocky trail conditons here in the Midwest (OK, AR, CO, NM). I'm a 50+ yr old trail rider who loves technical old-school hand-cut singletrack. I had previously run Vittorias for a few years (Mazzas and Motas most recently) that worked pretty well, but I was really impressed with the 2.4 Dissector. 
My '21 Tallboy came stock with a 2.4 Dissector up front and a 2.4 Recon in the rear. The Dissector is a great "middle-ground" trail tire that offers excellent grip for its moderate weight and low rolling resistance. Perfect for most of the conditions/trails I ride. The Recon was decent in the rear initially, but not grippy enough for loose, steep, climbs. I replaced it with the 2.4 Dissector (a much gripper tire), and really didn't notice any additional rolling resistance. Now my Tallboy has a 2.6 Dissector up front and a 2.4 in the rear. The 2.6 is probably overkill for most of the riding I do in OK, but it saved my bacon multiple times when riding deep sand here locally and on faster, more enduro-y terrain in AR and CO. Not much of a weight or rolling resistance penalty for running that much beef up front. Highly recommended!
review.name: Great All-Round Trail Bike Tire

review.itemreviewed: Dissector Wide Trail Dual Compound EXO/TR 29in Tire
review.reviewBody:
I've been riding Maxxis for several years, and I have a lot of experience with the Minion DHR and Minion DHR II.  I felt like the DHR II was sucking the life out of my ride, and I didn't like the weight of the Minions.  But I didn't want to sacrifice downhill traction - especially up front.  Then I discovered the Dissector.  What a pleasant surprise!!  The Dissector is about 8 ounces lighter than a Minion; that's about 1 lb lighter for two tires.  Everything about the Dissector seems better without sacrificing traction in cornering.  The first difference I noticed was how fast they roll compared to Minions.  Combine that with a weight savings and I'm hooked.  
Troy Brosnan designed the Dissector after the Minion DHF, but with a faster rolling center.  It was originally sold as a rear downhill tire, but Troy Brosnan won a world cup running it on front and rear.  So do I.  People gonna do what they gonna do, but remember that I said to try out the Dissector.
review.name: Best Under-rated All Mountain Tires

name: Dissector Wide Trail Dual Compound EXO/TR 29in Tire

review.reviewBody: I got these after really liking the matching TLD raid knee pads.  They feel true to size, a little snug but it sounds like they will relax a little from the other reviews, and I definitely prefer snug to loose.  They're not leaving a mark or anything, and the sleeve lets the breeze in.  Easy on/off, nice hard pad with a lot of forearm protection.  I was glad I went with this heavier pad vs. the leaner alternatives from TLD, although I haven't fallen in them yet - I just can't see much downside in the extra heft - I barely feel them climbing.  The top of the sleeve hides under a longish short sleeve shirt so there is no visible gap.
review.name: Just what I was looking for

review.reviewBody:
This is my third KASK Mojito so it’s safe to say I love this helmet! Looks great, fits perfect, lots of adjustments, and stays cool even on hot days. 

I think it fits true to size but, it may trend slightly small. I’m bald so, if you have a thick lock of hair like my kiddo, this helmet may run a bit small at your normal size.
review.name: My ATF helmet!

review.reviewBody: It’s a Good helmet with some premium feeling features. I like the form factor.
review.name: Cool helmet

review.reviewBody:
Replaced a mojito X with the cubed. The brim takes a bit of getting used to but does help quite a bit with keeping perspiration off your face. The octo fit system is overkill for me but the helmet does fit really well and is extremely comfortable. The octo  fit system does seem to require adjustments on the fly which I?m hoping is just me getting used to it. Purchased this and a Bell z20 MIPS and the Kask is much more comfortable and feels very solid. 

Update. First attempt at washing the removable padding and it?s falling apart before being hand washed. Not happy.
review.name: Super Comfortable

name: Mojito Cubed

review.reviewBody:
The Large in this jersey was kind of baggy for me. But, it was the recommended size according to GORE size chart. As I use it on the road, I like a more fitted appearance. I returned it as the color I wanted was not available in medium.
Update:
I now have the jerseys in medium and the fit is spot on! I liked it so much that I bought the Black, Grey, Green Light Red and Sphere Blue
(Jewel tone to the fabric) and now the Nordic Blue became available, so I purchased that one as well. Interesting fabric (melange)- It has a beautiful wool like outer appearance with a honeycomb texture inside. I pair them with Smartwool socks for the matching texture. I like the robust feel of the fabric, the 4th zippered rear pocket and the zipper garages at the neck and waist. Feature packed. What more can you ask for?!
review.name: I sized down and it works!

review.reviewBody: I?m 5-10, 160. I ordered a US XS/EU S (the smallest size available). Still has the dreaded bunching at the midsection. Back they go.
review.name: Fit is eno

review.reviewBody: This jersey is supposed to fit loose. Gore describes this as slim fit and their tight "race" style as form fitting; however, I ordered my normal medium size and it was much looser than expected so I returned it. It may have worked out if I sized down.
review.name: Loose Fit

name: C3 Jersey - Men's
